ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.2_0: At that time Venerable Udāyī was associating with and visiting a number of families in Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.3_0: At this time, when Udāyī saw a young man without a wife or a young woman without a husband, he would praise the young woman in the presence of the parents of the young man,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.4_0: “The young woman of such-and such a family is beautiful, intelligent, skilled, and diligent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.5_0: She is suitable for your daughter.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.7_0: “Venerable, they don’t know who we are,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.8_0: If you would persuade them to give the girl, we would take her for our son.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.9_0: if he praises the girl of the young man,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.10_0: “The young man of such-and-such a family is handsome, intelligent, skilled, and diligent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.11_0: He is suitable for your daughter.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.13_0: “Venerable, they don’t know who we are,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.14_0: and we would be ashamed to speak to them for the sake of the girl.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.15_0: But if you would persuade them to ask us, we would give our girl to the young man.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.1.16_0: In this way he arranged for the taking of a bride, for the giving of a bride, and for marriage.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.1_0: At that time there was a certain former courtesan who had a beautiful daughter.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.2_0: On one occasion some lay followers of the Ājīvaka religion came from another village and said to that courtesan,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.3_0: “Lady, please give your girl to our boy.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.4_0: “Sirs, I don’t know who you are.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.5_0: I’m not able to go beyond them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.6_0: Some people asked those Ājīvaka lay followers
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.8_0: and they replied, “We came to ask that courtesan to give her daughter to our son,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.10_0: I’m not able to go beyond them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.11_0: “But why did you ask the courtesan?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.12_0: You should speak to Venerable Udāyī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.15_0: “Venerable, we’ve asked that courtesan here to give her daughter to our son,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.18_0: Would you please persuade her to give us her daughter?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.19_0: Udāyī approached that courtesan and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.20_0: “Why didn’t you give them your daughter?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.21_0: “I don’t know who they are, Sir,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.22_0: I’m not able to go beyond them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.2.25_0: “If you know them, Sir, I’ll give you.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.1_0: She then gave her daughter to those Ājīvaka followers,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.2_0: and they took her away. For a month they treated her like a daughter-in-law,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.4_0: The girl sent a message to her mother:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.6_0: For a month they treated me like a daughter-in-law,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.8_0: Come, mum, and take me home.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.9_0: Soon afterwards the courtesan went to those Ājīvakas and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.10_0: “Please don’t treat my girl like a slave;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.13_0: “We deal with the ascetic, not with you.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.15_0: We don’t want to know you.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.16_0: Being dismissed, she returned to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.17_0: A second time the girl sent the same message to her mother.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.22_0: That courtesan then approached Udāyī and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.23_0: “Venerable, my girl is unhappy and miserable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.24_0: For a month they treated her like a daughter-in-law,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.27_0: ‘Please don’t treat my girl like a slave;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.29_0: Udāyī went to those Ājīvakas and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.30_0: “Please don’t treat this girl like a slave;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.35_0: you should behave like a good ascetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.37_0: We don’t want to know you.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.38_0: Being dismissed, he returned to Sāvatthī.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.44_0: and a second time the courtesan approached Udāyī and told him the same thing.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.45_0: “Venerable, my girl is unhappy and miserable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.46_0: For a month they treated her like a daughter-in-law,

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.3.50_0: He replied, “When I went the first time, they just dismissed me.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.1_0: Then that courtesan complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.2_0: “May Venerable Udāyī be miserable and unhappy, just as my girl is miserable and unhappy because of her nasty mother-in-law, nasty father-in-law, and nasty husband.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.3_0: And the girl, too, complained and criticized him in the same way,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.4_0: “May Venerable Udāyī be miserable and unhappy, just as my girl is miserable and unhappy because of her nasty mother-in-law, nasty father-in-law, and nasty husband.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.5_0: as did other women who were unhappy with their mothers-in-law, their fathers-in-law, and their husbands.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.6_0: “May Venerable Udāyī be miserable and unhappy, just as we are miserable and unhappy because of our nasty mother-in-law, nasty father-in-law, and nasty husband.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.7_0: But those women who were happy with their mothers-in-law, their fathers-in-law, and their husbands wished him well,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.4.8_0: “May Venerable Udāyī be happy and well, just as we are happy and well because of our good mothers-in-law, good fathers-in-law, and good husbands.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.1_0: The monks heard some women and others.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.2_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.3_0: “How can Venerable Udāyī act as a matchmaker?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.5_0: The Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Udāyī:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.6_0: “Is it true, Udāyī, that you acted as a matchmaker?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.9_0: “... Foolish man, how can you act as a matchmaker?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.10_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.11_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.12.1_0: ‘If a monk acts as a matchmaker, conveying a man’s intentions to a woman or a woman’s intentions to a man, for marriage or for an affair, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:1.5.13_0: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:4.1.1_0: There are ten kinds of women: the one protected by her mother, the one protected by her father, the one protected by her parents, the one protected by her brother, the one protected by her sister, the one protected by her relatives, the one protected by her kinsmen, the one protected by her religion, the one otherwise protected, the one protected by the threat of punishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:4.1.2_0: There are ten kinds of wives: the bought wife, the wife by choice, the wife through property, the wife through clothes, the wife through the bowl-of-water ritual, the wife through removing the head pad, the slave wife, the servant wife, the captured wife, the momentary wife.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:4.2.1_0: The one protected by her mother:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:4.2.2_0: her parents protect, guards, wields authority, controls.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.1_0: At one time a man told a monk,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.2_0: “Sir, find out about such-and-such a woman.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.3_0: When the monk got there, he asked some people,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.7_0: “The Buddha has laid down a training rule,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.8_0: Could it be that I’ve committed an offense entailing suspension?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.9_0: He told the Buddha, who said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.1.11_0: but there’s an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.2.1_0: At one time a man told a monk,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.2.2_0: “Sir, find out about such-and-such a woman.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.2.3_0: When the monk got there, he asked some people,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.2.8_0: “That’s a woman who lacks sexual organs, Venerable.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.2.11_0: but there’s an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.3.1_0: On one occasion a woman who was arguing with her husband went to his house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.3.2_0: A monk who associated with that family reconciled them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.3.6_0: “There’s no offense when they’re not divorced.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.4.1_0: At one time a monk acted as a matchmaker for _paṇḍakas_.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss5:5.4.5_0: The fifth rule, the training rule on matchmaking, is finished.
